title: 109_s452
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Tsunami Early Warning and Relief Act of 2005". The Congress acknowledges the devastating impact of the 2004 tsunami in South Asia, Southeast Asia, and East Africa, resulting in over 160,000 deaths and leaving more than 140,000 people missing. The affected countries include Indonesia, Sri Lanka, India, Thailand, and others, requiring both short-term survival and long-term rehabilitation assistance. The 2004 tsunami caused historic destruction, separating families and orphaning children. A global tsunami warning system is crucial for preventing future disasters and protecting national security. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has already built a system of tsunami buoys in the Pacific Ocean to enhance the nation's response to tsunamis. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration can upgrade its tsunami warning system globally with consistent funding and international cooperation. Local emergency management capabilities are essential for relaying tsunami warnings to coastal communities. TITLE I--TSUNAMI WARNING SYSTEMS

SEC. 101. GLOBAL PROGRAM. The Secretary of Commerce will establish a Global Tsunami Disaster Reduction Program to create a warning system for vulnerable areas worldwide. The program will involve international cooperation to share costs, data, and technical advice for implementation and evacuation plans. The Global Earth Observation System of Systems program aims to have access to and openly share all relevant information worldwide. The Director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will expand the United States Tsunami Ready program by working with coastal communities to improve tsunami information dissemination and evacuation plans. They will also enhance seismic activity monitoring through the Global Seismic Network to support the program. An annual report will be submitted. The Director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will provide an annual report to Congress on the progress of carrying out the program. The term "United States" is defined to include various states and territories. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2006 and beyond. Assistance related to the Indian Ocean Tsunami is also provided. SEC. 201. ASSISTANCE.

The President, through the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, is authorized to provide assistance for the relief, rehabilitation, and reconstruction of countries affected by the Indian Ocean tsunami.

SEC. 202. REPORT.

The President will submit quarterly and biannual reports to Congress in 2005 and 2006, respectively, on the progress of the assistance provided.

SEC. 203. DEFINITION. SEC. 203. DEFINITION.

The term ``Indian Ocean tsunami'' refers to the tsunami caused by the 2004 earthquake off the coast of Sumatra, Indonesia.

SEC. 204. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funds are authorized for the President to use for this title in fiscal year 2006 and beyond.
